H0.text: Plaque fragments are what can travel via the bloodstream and become lodged in other arteries when rupture occurs.

H1.text: Enamel is the material whose fragments can travel via the bloodstream and become lodged in other arteries when rupture occurs.

H2.text: Red blood cells are fragments that can travel via the bloodstream and become lodged in other arteries when rupture occurs.

H3.text: White blood cells are fragments that, after rupture, can travel through the bloodstream and become lodged in other arteries.

A4.text: If the fibrous cap separating a soft atheroma from the bloodstream within the artery ruptures, tissue fragments are exposed and released.

A5.text: These tissue fragments are very clot-promoting, containing collagen and tissue factor; they activate platelets and activate the system of coagulation.
